description:
In Nova API Sample file testing, https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/tests/integrated/api_samples_test_base.py#L272  file has the expression for DATETIME in 'timestamp' variable as mentioned below- 
                         '\d{4}-[0,1]\d-[0-3]\d[ ,T]'
                         '\d{2}:\d{2}:\d{2}'
                         '(Z|(\+|-)\d{2}:\d{2}|\.\d{6}|)',
Which is right enough to check the existing written API test. But It needs to be extended where DATETIME can come in below format-
                             "2014-03-28 07:05:11.726547+00:00"
where Time Zone can come with microseconds also (.726547+00:00). This combination is not supported in existing expression.

Currently above mentioned DATETIME format comes in NOVA V2 GET /keypairs/<key_name> API XML response. Its API sample file and their test is not written yet thats why no failure in test results.

We need to extend the DATETIME expression to accompalish the format return by above API.
title: DATETIME expression in api_samples_test_base.py format is not sufficient

comments.content: Hmm... ISO9601 does not define support for microseconds with the Z or +/- TZ offset format. I believe that a more appropriate fix would be to ensure any output returned from the keypairs extension is *either* in the microsecond format (with no TZ identifier) *or* does not include a microsecond part and *does* include the TZ part.

comments.content:
Thanks Jay for giving me the direction to find out the root cause.

Root Cause-
In nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/keypairs.py -> show(), tzinfo needs to be corrected by making it None in datetime object. This is how it was stored in database. 
When database value is stored in datetime object (https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/objects/base.py#L437), TZ also gets added here.  If in database, created time is being stored with microsecond also then, microsecond and TZ both comes in created_at format. 
So we need to strip the tzinfo while returing the response.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ghanshyammann

comments.content:
Ok, I've added a bunch more information here: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-April/033971.html

A couple of things to note ...

1) This only affects the XML serialization; for XML we just do str(datetime), whereas for JSON we do timeutils.strtime(datetime)

2) The combination of microseconds and tz info is actually a valid timestamp. It's not actually an ISO8601 timestamp, but we don't use the ISO8601 format in our XML output

So ... I think this bug is valid. The XML sample validation should allow a str(datetime) timestamp which includes both timezone and microsecond information.
